I was afraid it was going to be a watery mess, but it wasn't! It held together very well. I ended up doubling the recipe because I made too much squash (I roasted 2 but could have done with 1). I roasted the squash the night before when I had the oven on to make enchiladas. I let them cool, pulled the strands out, and refrigerated them overnight. The next day I poured off the water that had gathered in the bottom and layered according to directions. I just made one big 9x13 and realized I might need extra cooking time, so I cranked up the heat to 450 until it was bubbling, uncovered for about 10 minutes and it was perfect. We started with a salad course to let it rest a bit and firm up.\r\n\r\nI think an issue of too much moisture could be helped by roasting the night before and setting in a colander in a bowl in the fridge overnight. Roll the tortilla up from the bottom to surround the filling and once it\u2019s rolled into a tube, place it on the prepared baking sheet, seam side down. Next I add wedges of onion, sliced jalape\u00f1o, cilantro leaves &amp; stems and pulse until finely chopped. Lastly I add the whole shrimp and tomato wedges and pulse until they are coarsely chopped. I heat the oil in a hot skillet, saut\u00e9 until cooked through, adding the salt &amp; pepper at the end. I soaked the red onions in cold water first, which tamed their sharp flavor quite nicely. \u00a0Then I separated them into much smaller chunks (two layers or so) for the skewers, so that they would cook as quickly as the shrimp. \u00a0I brushed some sauce on the skewers before grilling, and salted everything thereafter. \u00a0We both really liked it. \u00a0It would also be good with chicken, if you're not a fan of shrimp. \u00a0I ran out of curry paste, or I probably would have added more, but this amount gave a pleasant warmth! \u00a0Sizing the veggies appropriately is really important if you want to grill on the same skewers as the shrimp. \u00a0For me, an eighth of a (typically huge) red onion is way too thick for grilling along with shrimp, but two-layer sections worked great. \u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Julie Hordyk"}, "datePublished": "2021-09-14"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Enjoy Indian spiced recipes. I held my breath as I did do a bit of change which was: since didn't have 11 ounces of banana, more like 9.3, added a half cup applesauce, I also usually get away with no butter but did add one tab light butter. There was a difference in directions of 1.5 cup flour or 8 ounces but 1.5 cup weighs more like 6.3 ounces--so I went with the 6.3. They turned out perfectly--I made 12 muffins. So either I was lucky or this is a forgiving recipe. I also added a dash of cinnamon, nutmeg and cardamon as I love spices. So worked out great and would do again.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Frances"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-13"}], "recipeCategory": ["Breakfast", "Brunch", "Snack"], "recipeCuisine": My favorite lentil chili has red pepper in it, so I was very excited to see that in the list here.  I feel it really adds something to the flavor that is missing in standard chili recipes.\r\nSomehow I made mine pretty spicy, but I had a mild cold that week so honestly my sinuses needed it! "name": "How do I grate ginger?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "First, use a spoon to peel off the ginger\u2019s skin. This step is optional because the skin is edible. To grate it, rub the ginger root on a microplane. You can either do this over a cutting board to measure out 1 tablespoon or directly over the soup pot if you prefer to eyeball it. (You can also use ginger paste to save time).", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/pumpkin-ginger-coconut-soup/#faq-question-1762878627272", "position": 2, "url": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/pumpkin-ginger-coconut-soup/#faq-question-1762878627272", "name": "What can I use if I don\u2019t have an immersion blender for soup?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Immersion blenders, also called stick blenders, are extremely convenient for pureeing soups. However, if you don\u2019t own one, a regular blender will do. Here are a couple of tips: 1. Do it in batches to ensure you don\u2019t overfill the pitcher. 2. Place the lid on the blender, remove the clear plastic cap, and cover it with a dish towel so steam can escape. I personally prefer this with peeled apples", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/apple-butter-recipe/#faq-question-1757685941152", "position": 2, "url": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/apple-butter-recipe/#faq-question-1757685941152", "name": "What is the difference between apple butter and applesauce?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Both apple butter and applesauce start with the same base\u2014cooked apples\u2014but the cooking process and final texture are different. Applesauce is cooked until the apples are soft and then pureed into a smooth, spoonable consistency. Apple butter is cooked much longer, allowing the sugars in the apples to caramelize. This gives it a darker color, thicker texture, and a more concentrated, spiced flavor. Think of applesauce as light and fresh, while apple butter is rich, spreadable, and almost jam-like.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/apple-butter-recipe/#faq-question-1757686121101", "position": 3, "url": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/apple-butter-recipe/#faq-question-1757686121101", "name": "Is apple butter just jam?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Not exactly. Apple butter is similar to jam because it\u2019s a thick, spreadable fruit preserve, but the process and flavor are different. Jams are typically made by cooking fruit with sugar and sometimes pectin until they gel. Apple butter, on the other hand, is made by slowly cooking apples down for hours until the natural sugars caramelize. The result is darker, smoother, and more intensely flavored than jam\u2014without the need for added thickeners.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Recipe", "name": "Apple Butter Recipe (Stovetop)", "author": {"@id": "https://www.skinnytaste.com/#/schema/person/d30ee2b4f0b2b8cff8d010fbf4228b72"}, "description": "This homemade apple butter is thick, smooth, and full of warm fall spices\u2014made right on your stovetop. And, the proportions were quite far off. \u00a0I planned to make 24 instead of 12....I didn't increase the leeks at all and I had tons of leftover. \u00a0I also only used about 2 lbs. of potatoes. \u00a0Again, I know it matters how big your tins are, but a note to the wise that this is not a perfectly proportioned recipe. \u00a0I would definitely make them again....they were yummy and a big hit!\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Julie Hordyk"}, "datePublished": "2021-04-08"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "I made this for Easter\r\nDinner using Boursin cheese... it was the highlight of the meal!\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kathie Todd"}, "datePublished": "2021-04-04"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "reviewBody": "Made it for Easter and it was a huge hit.
